tossups.question: Richard Baillie et al. added fractionally integrated parameters to a class of models which introduce [emphasize] this property to model the diffusion of innovations. One can use the “sandwich estimator” to obtain a set of parameters that are robust against this property, named for Huber and White. Tim Bollersev introduced a class of autoregressive models which assume this property under some circumstances called GARCH (“garch”), which extend Robert Engle’s methods for modeling shocks to stock prices by introducing the (*) “conditional” form of this property. GMM estimators are more efficient than one or two-stage ordinary least squared estimators if the data have this property. Data can be assumed to have this issue if the null hypothesis is rejected in a Breusch-Pagan test, which regresses the squared residuals of a data set on the independent variable. For 10 points, name this property of data sets whose variance is not constant.
tossups.answer: heteroscedasticity [or heteroskedastic; prompt on scedasticity; prompt on non-constant variance or equivalent answers indicating a variance is not consistent across the data]

tossups.question: This character quotes Cicero, who noted how Rome’s fame had “not yet crossed the Caucasus,” to explain why “each must be content to have the range of his glory limited to his own people.” This character commands “Speak out, hide it not in thy heart” in explaining that one who desires “physician’s help” must “disclose thy wound.” 13 lost songs addressed to this character are reconstructed in an album by Sequentia. This character likens independence to being both a “rudder and helm” in a passage explaining that (*) God represents “absolute happiness.” This character wears a gown which represents practical and theoretical realms with the Greek letters pi and theta. This character calls her interlocutor the “stupidest of mortals” for seeking to hold still the turning “wheel of Fortune” and resist imprisonment by Theodoric. For 10 points, name this allegorical woman who consoles Boethius.
tossups.answer: Lady Philosophy [or Philosophia; accept The Consolation of Philosophy]

tossups.question: These people wrote down their customs, which they called cawarfidae (“kah-WAR-fih-dye”), in a type of great meeting called an “assembly of spears” or gaerethinx (“GUY-reh-thinks”). These people’s king Perctarit is the last mentioned in a text which relates their origin in Scandanan under the rule of Queen Gambara. The federated kingdom of these people was administered by officials called gastalds under the laws of the Edictum Rothari. Supposedly after a god saw these people at (*) sunrise, he granted them victory and changed their name from the Winnili. In what is called the Donation of Sutri, these people’s king Liutprand (“L’YOOT-prahnd”) gave land to Gregory II. Their chief historian, Paul the Deacon, relates the feats of families among them who came to rule the duchies of Friuli and Benevento. For 10 points, Charlemagne’s enemy Desiderius was a king of what Germanic people who, in the late 6th century, conquered Italy from the Byzantines?
tossups.answer: Lombards [or Langobards or Longobardi; prompt on Long Beards or Winnili]

tossups.question: The Delacor Queued Message Handler tool for this software is ideal for handling communications between multiple parallel modules running at different rates. The Bytes At Port property in this software causes weird race conditions during serial communication, which is implemented in this software with programs from the VISA driver. The Functional Global Variable pattern is used in this software to share data safely. This proprietary software interfaces well with CompactDAQ and CompactRIO devices, which are made by the same company. This software creates programs in G, a (*) dataflow language. In this software, the block diagram shows how wires move data from sources, such as control terminals, to sinks, such as indicator terminals. Programs created with this software are called VIs. For 10 points, name this National Instruments graphical programming software used for data acquisition and testing.
tossups.answer: LabVIEW [or Laboratory Virtual Instrument Engineering Workbench]

tossups.question: A piece in this genre begins with the notes [read slowly] “A, up to F, E-flat, C, B” followed by a held E-flat accompanied by pizzicato notes in the basses. An alternate arrangement of that posthumously-finished example of these pieces was created by the composer’s son Peter, with Paul Neubauer. Another of these pieces quotes the folk song “Nun laube, Lindlein” in the second of its three movements, all based on German folk songs. When King George V died two days before the British premiere of that piece in this genre, the composer wrote a mournful piece for the same set of performers titled (*) Trauermusik (“TROW-er-moo-zeek”). Bela Bartok’s example of these pieces was completed and orchestrated by his friend Tibor Serly. Paul Hindemith’s Der Schwanendreher (“dare SHVAH-nen-dray-ur”) is one of these pieces, as is a piece dedicated "To Christabel" and written for Lionel Tertis by William Walton. For 10 points, identify these pieces for orchestra and a soloist playing an oft-mocked string instrument.

In a novella, a woman living in this city abuses her daughter into taking opium due to her paranoia regarding the fortune she inherited from her crippled husband, the “Second Master.” In a satirical novel, several students who return from France to this city aboard a steamer discuss a French proverb which likens marriage to the title place, where “those who are outside want to get in, and those…inside want to get out.” This city is the setting of The Golden Cangue (“kang”) as well as a novel in which a Russian prisoner gives two cyanide capsules to his comrades, leaving himself to be (*) burned alive in a train boiler. The novel Fortress Besieged is set in this city, as is a novel in which a Comintern cell meets at the Black Cat Club and Hemmelrich’s shop, where the Baron Clappique (“klah-PEEK”) organizes shipments of smuggled weapons for an uprising planned by Kyo Gisors. For 10 points, what Chinese city is the setting of André Malraux’s novel Man’s Fate?

Dixon et al’s kinetic modulatory profiling method showed that the SERM (“serm”) bazedoxifene (“BAY-zed-OX-uh-feen”) inhibits this process. The masked nitrile-oxide M·L·2·1·0 and the chloro·acet·amide-containing R·S·L·3 are common inhibitors of a critical enzyme that prevents this process. A·S·C·L·4 and L·P·C·A·T·3 produce P·U·F·As to act as substrates during this process. This process was named in a 2012 paper by Stockwell et al, who induced it in a RAS-mutant cell line using erastin. P·5·3 potentiates this process by decreasing expression of S·L·C·7·A·11, which is one component of system X-sub-c-minus, a (*) cystine/glutamate antiporter. The canonical method of triggering this process is by inhibiting glutathione peroxidase 4, which leads to widespread lipid peroxidation via increased reactive oxygen species. For 10 points, name this form of programmed cell death that is iron-dependent.
tossups.answer: ferroptosis [prompt on cell death, or programmed cell death, or pcd, or apoptosis; prompt on lipid peroxidation, or lipid oxidation, or free radicals damaging lipids, or reactive oxygen species attacking lipids, etc. by asking “what does that lead to?”]

tossups.question: One work by this artist contains a life-sized depiction of his patron Eleanor of Aragon as a green-draped Mary Magdalene. In the 1920s Lionel Cust attributed a terra cotta bust of a seven-year old Henry VIII to this artist, who was considered but ultimately rejected for the Tomb of Henry VII. This artist’s masterpiece depicts a woman known as Suor Papina, who blows on a spoon of food the moment before feeding an infant Jesus. After this artist was knighted, he was commissioned to design the now-destroyed tomb of Charles VIII. The lack of a quarrying business in his home city of (*) Modena meant that this artist had to use a material that enabled him to make polychrome sculptures of religious works, such as his Lamentation for a church in Ferrara. A vibrant, colorful depiction of Adoration of the Shepherds was made by, for 10 points, what 15th century sculptor considered to be the Renaissance master of terracotta?

This book’s introduction analyzes the “mistake” of an anthropologist who assumed that the Sirionó (“see-ree-oh-NO”) people had “no real history” by explaining results from LIDAR scans in the province of Beni. This book cites the work of Ruth Shady to argue that the first “realm of King Cotton” was created over 5,000 years ago in the environs of Caral. Its last chapter notes how the “second oldest...existing representative parliament” on Earth was established by the Great Peacemaker. This book attacks the (*) “pristine myth” cultivated by accounts such as that of Sir Francis Drake, arguing instead that its subjects were “everywhere a keystone species,” as demonstrated by Maya slash-and-burn agriculture. This 2005 book favors arguments by “High Counters” who claim the Americas had more people than Europe in the 15th century. For 10 points, what book by Charles Mann is titled for the year [emphasize] before the first trans-Atlantic voyage of Columbus?

A paper by this author imagines worlds in which unicorns can either be members of order Artiodactyla or Perissodactyla to show that modal logic’s “Axiom B” must be false. In a chapter titled “Ingredients of Meaning,” this thinker argued that a “theory of force” is needed to construct “meaning-theories.” Crispin Wright attacked this contemporary of his for a theory of “revisionism” which effectively abandoned the useful results of classical logics. He examined the view that sentences’ truth value are independent of the external world, which he termed (*) “anti-realism,” in the 1982 paper “Realism.” This commentator argued that an earlier philosopher used quantifiers to invent a “formal language” in two books subtitled “Philosophy of Language” and “Philosophy of Mathematics.” The Logical Basis of Metaphysics was written by, for 10 points, what British philosopher known for his commentaries on Gottlob Frege (“FRAY-guh”)?
tossups.answer: Michael Dummett [or Sir Sir Michael Anthony Eardley Dummett]

tossups.question: The leader of the women’s division of this party, dubbed the “Red Princess,” was its only leading figure to not confess to spying on live TV during a series of trials in which many of this party’s members were executed by “Hanging Judge” Lajevardi. This party was founded by disaffected princes of a deposed dynasty who were members of the “group of fifty-three,” some of whom were brought into Ahmad Qavam’s unity government. Many of this party’s members joined the Dehghani faction of People’s Fedai Guerillas, which organized revolts in (*) Mazandaran province, in the aftermath of the Sino-Soviet Split. Despite helping organize a revolt after the Jaleh Square Massacre, this leftist party was banned four years later in 1983 by the very government it helped bring to power. Throughout the 1970s, Evin Prison contained many members of this party who had been jailed by the SAVAK secret police. For 10 points, name this Iranian communist party.
tossups.answer: Tudeh Party of Iran [or Ḥezb-e Tūde-ye Īrān or Party of the Masses of Iran; prompt on Communist Party of Persia or Communist Party of Iran]

tossups.question: After being asked about a “blonde on a train,” a member of this family says “There is no present or future--only the past happening over and over again--now.” That member of this family makes fun of his wealthy neighbor, who accuses him of allowing pigs to freely intrude on his ice pond. A member of this family attacks his father’s miserly nature by calling him “Old Gaspard” and says “Thanks, Kid. I certainly had that coming” after his younger brother punches him for calling their mother a “hophead.” That member of this family confesses to being too (*) drunk to attend his mother’s funeral, and that his plan to sell land to his unfriendly neighbor Harder was complete BS, to a woman who seduced him named Josie. The play A Moon for the Misbegotten features this family’s member Jamie. For 10 points, name this family which includes the morphine addict Mary and is central to Long Day’s Journey Into Night.
tossups.answer: Tyrone family [accept Jamie Tyrone or Mary Tyrone]

tossups.question: One program used for predicting this quantity uses empirically derived hypersurfaces from Ref·D·B. Metal tags are used to induce this quantity through pseudocontact. P·S·S·I and PANAV are methods of re-referencing this quantity. The span and the skew are calculated from the principal components of this quantity’s tensor in the Herzfeld-Berger convention, which describes this quantity’s anisotropy. Wishart developed a method of indexing secondary forms of quantity in which 0 corresponds to a random coil. Assigning these quantities to the amide (*) backbone is the main step in a method of determining protein structure in solution. A ring current increases this quantity in aromatic molecules, while electron-donating groups increase it by shielding. This quantity is calculated from frequency using D·S·S, T·S·P, or T·M·S as a standard to normalize for field strength. For 10 points, name this quantity expressed in parts per million, which differs for every non-equivalent atom in N·M·R.

Besides designing a “boomerang desk,” Maurice Calka is best-known for his sculpture of this animal made of black stone, found on Churchill Avenue. In 2016, thousands of flags showing this animal were held aloft by worshippers honoring a state visit by Prince Ermias. A prophecy from Genesis 49 about the time before the “coming of Shiloh” inspired depictions of this animal holding a long, thin scepter with a cross. In the Book of Revelation, a seven-horned lamb and this animal are the only ones which can (*) open the seventh seal. A praise song declares this animal “Shall Break Every Chain and Give Us a Victory Again and Again.” On April 21, 1976, an imperial flag showing this royal animal against a red, yellow, and green background was flown on the first Grounation Day to honor Haile Selassie. Many Rastafari worshipers wear dreadlocks to emulate the mane of, for 10 points, what conquering feline named for an Israelite tribe?
tossups.answer: The Lion of Judah [prompt on feline; prompt on lion or leo with “we want a specific Biblical lion”]

tossups.question: In a contemporary review, critic Phil Leider praised this artwork as the most political and important work of art conceived since Guernica. Footage of this artwork is juxtaposed with the director’s mother administrative duties in a documentary by Renee Green. The artist had the building operator Rich Helmling use a backhoe to split a board to help create this artwork, a move that the artist analogized to “the breaking of Humpty Dumpty.” Five years after it was completed, it was destroyed by arsonists to the chagrin of the artist’s widow (*) Nancy Holt, who had earlier lobbied for its preservation. The artist of this work originally wanted to use a giant mudslide to help create this work but, due to impracticality, decided instead to use firewood to fill the title structure. Only a plaque and mounds of mulch and dirt remain of this artwork, which was conceived as an illustration of entropy. Kent State University is the site of, for 10 points, what building by Robert Smithson?

The aphoristic book Hidden Words was originally named for this figure and is held by modern Bahá'ís to be the fulfillment of a set of lost prophecies given to this figure. In a book titled for this figure, Ali Shariati claimed that the question of "who am I?'' was only able to be fulfilled by the Iranian Revolution. This figure names a type of tasbih that involves repeating the subḥāna -llah, al-ḥamdu lillāh, and  ʾallāhu ʾakbaru 33 times each. According to one tradition, this figure died after being crushed in a door by a group of men led by (*) Umar, an event mourned for three days in Iraq during a namesake holiday. This figure's Sermon of Fadak has been used by Islamic feminists to advocate for gender equality in property rights. In Iran this figure is honored as "the greater Mary'' and her birthday is celebrated as National Women's Day. For 10 points, name this women revered in Shia Islam, the daughter of Muhamma and wife of Ali.

This poem likely refers to a settlement in Georgia with its verses about the “horrid shores” of “wild Altama,” where “silent bats in drowsy clusters cling” and “the dark scorpion gathers death around.” This poem’s speaker thrice laments “I still had hopes,” such as a hope “to return—and die at home at last,” after remarking “glades forlorn confess the tyrant’s power.” It personifies the title place as a “charming nymph” who is the “source of all my bliss, and all my woe,” and asks her to “teach erring man to spurn the rage of (*) gain.” This poem describes a place whose “lovely bowers” were “Seats of my youth, when every sport could please,” and whose “states of native strength” have been harmed by “trade’s proud empire.” It declares “Ill fares the land, to hastening ills a prey” and that a “bold peasantry...when once destroyed, can never be supplied.” For 10 points, name this pastoral poem about the decline of “Sweet Auburn,” written by Oliver Goldsmith.

After Fatma Betül Sayan Kaya’s planned pro-Erdogan rally in this city was cancelled, Turkey expelled all ambassadors from the country where this city is located. Islamist parties headquartered in this city include NIDA (“NEE-dah”), which has close ties to Hamas, and the more moderate Denk party, both of whom oppose its ethnically Berber mayor Ahmed Aboutaleb. An openly gay politician from this city critized Islam as a “backward culture” and formed his own list of candidates to win its local elections in 2002, after which he was murdered by an environmental activist. In 2013 this (*) European city’s shoreline became the home of a “vertical city” of office buildings and flats designed by the Office for Metropolitan Architecture, which is headquartered here. Pim Fortuyn (“peem for-TUN”) was from this city, much of which was designed by hometown architect Rem Koolhaas. For 10 points, name this largest port in Europe and second-largest city in the Netherlands.

During a TV appearance, this person joked that “both books were destroyed” when Ronald Reagan’s library burned down, but the “real horror” was that Reagan “hadn’t finished coloring either one of them.” The film The Man Who Said No depicts this person’s campaign against Jerry Brown in the 1982 Democratic Senate primary in California. Jay Parini’s biography Empire of Self describes this person being thrown out of the White House by Bobby Kennedy for drunkenly putting his arm around Jackie. Late in life, he wrote a book blaming the “Cheney-Bush junta” for 9-11, titled (*) Dreaming War. In a series of 10 debates on ABC News, this man labeled the host of Firing Line a “crypto-Nazi,” which earned the response “I'll sock you in the goddamn face” from that man, the founder of the National Review. For 10 points, name this author of the “narratives of empire” and Myra Breckenridge who famously debated William F. Buckley.
tossups.answer: Gore Vidal [or Eugene Luther Gore Vidal]

tossups.question: Daniel Jonathan and Martin B. Plenio showed that states with this property can act as “catalysts” to allow otherwise impossible transformations to be performed in an intriguing consequence of Nielsen’s theorem. The “squashed” measure of this property is additive and asymptotically continuous. In a landmark paper, Bennett, Bernstein, Popescu, and Schumacher showed that n copies of a state with this property could be transformed into k copies of a state with this property enhanced. Special superpositions of photons called NOON states, which have this property, can be used as the basis for quantum interferometry. States with the (*) bound form of this property, such as states with positive partial transpose, cannot be distilled. Measures of this property do not increase under LOCC transformations. A Schmidt rank greater than one must be possessed by states that have, for 10 points, what property that is the subject of the EPR paradox?

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the Slovene-American author Louis Adamic (“AH-duh-mich”):
answers: jungle [accept Laughing in the Jungle or The Jungle]
Nero Wolfe [accept either underlined portion] (He was created by Rex Stout.)
parts: Adamic’s autobiographical novel about life in urban Los Angeles is titled for “laughing in” this place. The novel is an homage to an earlier novel about Jurgis Rudkus (“YUR-ghiss RUD-kus”) also titled for this place.

Rex Stout, who created this orchid-loving Montenegrin detective, modeled many of his characteristics on Adamic. Archie Goodwin assists this detective, who does almost all his work from his New York City brownstone.

This New York-based literary agent published the works of Adamic and other socialist writers along with his business partner, Jacob Howard Lewis. This agent fled the U.S. for Poland after being named by Whittaker Chambers as an accomplice of Alger Hiss.

bonuses.leadin: This period is named for the fictitious nobleman Gottlieb, who was used as a pseudonym to write parodic poems about contemporary taste for the magazine Fliegende Blätter (“FLEE-gen-duh BLEH-tur”). For 10 points each:
answers: Tsar Alexander I [prompt on Tsar Alexander]
parts: Give this term for the period of cultural history between the Vienna Congress and the Revolutions of 1848, exemplified by the tastes of the rising Austrian middle class in furniture and interior design.
Culture in the Biedermeier period was heavily influenced by the censorship perpetrated by this Austrian statesman, who resigned as Chancellor during the Revolutions of 1848.

In a letter to this person, Metternich included the essay “Confession of Political Faith,” which defends censorship by saying “We are certainly not alone in questioning if society can exist with the liberty of the press.” This person was encouraged to support Metternich’s ideas by the spiritual adviser Barbara von Krüdener.

bonuses.leadin: This term is used to describe a collection of viruses which has a large spectrum of mutations. For 10 points each:
answers: Fisher’s fundamental theorem of natural selection [prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this term developed by Eigen and Schuster as part of the theory of hypercycles, which consists of a cloud of rapidly mutating self-replicating genotypes.

A quasispecies is dominated by the sequence with the highest value for this quantity, which is the average contribution to the genepool of a unit of selection to the next generation. Evolution is often summarized as survival of the organisms with the highest value of this quantity.
This important result in evolutionary biology states that the rate of increase of fitness in a population is directly proportional to the genetic variance in fitness of that population.

bonuses.leadin: The likely-intersex artist Hosteen Klah was accused of sacrilege for adapting his people's sacred material into woven artworks. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Native American tribe whose weavings traditionally use the wool of a namesake type of churro sheep. This tribe's silver and turquoise necklaces frequently depict the squash blossom motif.

In particular, Klah was accused of sacrilege for adapting traditional Navajo artworks made of this material, which depict “places where the gods come and go” and are created before healing ceremonies. In Tibet, artworks made of this material are often created with the assistance of chakpur.
Like rugs and blankets, these objects are frequently woven by Navajo artists, who utilize the coil technique to depict spiralling patterns when making them from wicker or pine needles

bonuses.leadin: Maimonides argued that this taboo was adopted for health reasons, a theory which some later anthropologists agreed with, suggesting that this taboo helped avoid trichinosis infections. For 10 points each:
answers: taboo on eating pork [accept reasonable equivalent answers which indicate that you can’t eat pork or don’t eat pigs; reject “eating” or “not eating”]
symbolic boundaries [prompt on boundary or boundaries; reject “border”]
parts: Identify this taboo found in both Jewish and Muslim dietary laws, which is aimed at a certain split-hoofed animal that does not chew the cud.

In Purity and Danger, Mary Douglas cites Maimonides to argue that dietary laws served to maintain these distinctions. Émile Durkheim’s definition of “sacred” and “profane” is cited by Michèle Lamont as the first sociological analysis of these distinctions, which Lamont contrasts with “social” counterparts.

This anthropologist examined the paradoxes of pork prohibition in such books as The Sacred Cow and the Abominable Pig and Cows, Pigs, Wars, and Witches. He also wrote The Rise of Anthropological Theory.

bonuses.leadin: The interaction energy between a point charge and two of these ideal objects parallel to each other is exactly expressed using the digamma function and the Euler–Mascheroni constant. For 10 points each:
answers: infinite conducting plates [or infinite metallic plates; accept surfaces of conductors; prompt on conductors]
2nL plus z-prime OR 2nL plus z-prime [accept 2nL + z’ OR 2nL - z’; accept answers that are equivalent up to commutativity, i.e. accept 2Ln plus z-prime]
Riemann zeta function [prompt on zeta function]
parts: Name these objects that produce an electric field with magnitude sigma over epsilon-naught, while infinite sheets of charge give off a similar electric field with magnitude sigma over twice epsilon-naught

Two parallel conducting plates, one at z equals zero and one at z equals L and a point charge between them at z-prime can be solved by placing infinitely many image charges at this function of z-prime, L, and the image charge index n. You have 10 seconds to give the formula for the location of either the positive or negative image charges.

If the point charge is close to one of the plates, the interaction energy can be written with this function, which crops up in many physical systems. The nontrivial zeros of this function are related to the distribution of primes.

bonuses.leadin: In the Maxims of Ptahhotep, this concept is contrasted with a transgressor who is punished, noting how this concept "has not been disturbed since the day of its creator." For 10 points each:
answers: plumb line [or plummet; or plumb bob; or measure line]
parts: Give this central concept from ancient Egyptian philosophy and ethics. Failing to uphold this difficult to translate concept was believed to lead to isfet, or chaos. The original language term is required.

Upholding Ma'at and living a righteous life is compared to one of these objects in the Maxims of Ptahhotep. These objects, which are commonly used as a metaphor for virtue, was used in the book of Amos as a metaphor for a righteous leader.
Appeals to acting in accordance with Ma'at were also central to the persuasive methods of this field. In a book titled for this field, Aristotle divided this field into ethos, logos, and pathos.

bonuses.leadin: In Athenian society, this term denoted men such as Isaeus who worked as speechwriters. For 10 points each:
answers: logographers [or logographos or logographoi or logographi]
parts: Give this term which was applied by Thucydides to the Ionian historians and geographers from before the era of Herodotus, such as Xanthus of Lydia and Hecataeus of Miletus.

The lives of Hellanicus of Lesbos and many other logographers are mostly known to us thanks to this sprawling Byzantine encyclopedia with over 30,000 entries, which was probably compiled in the 10th century.
A Milesian of this name is often given as the oldest of the logographers. The Suda lists that man with a mythological prince of this name who founded Thebes.

bonuses.leadin: This place is not illuminated by “rays from the Holy Heaven,” but rather by light that streams “Up domes—up spires—up kingly halls— / Up fanes—up Babylon-like walls.” For 10 points each:
answers: Edgar Allan Poe (The latter poem is Annabel Lee.)
parts: Name this place which contains “time-eaten towers” and a “wilderness of glass.” This place titles a poem which claims it is “Where the good and the bad and the worst and the best / Have gone to their eternal rest.”
“The City in the Sea” is one of many poems which this author set in dismal, fantastic places. The title woman of another of his poems lives in a “kingdom by the sea.”

Poe’s poem “Dream-Land” likens its title location, ruled by an “Eidolon named NIGHT,” to a version of this place “For the spirit that walks in shadow.” In another poem by Poe, a “pilgrim shadow” points a knight towards this place, which is “Over the Mountains / Of the Moon.”

bonuses.leadin: Among the most authentic attempts at this task was accomplished at Yale in February 2010 thanks to the doctoral research of Anna Gawboy. For 10 points each:
answers: performing Prometheus Poem of Fire [accept any answer indicating putting on a proper performance of Prometheus, Poem of Fire, or premiering Prometheus, etc.]
color organ [or clavier à lumières or tastiera per luce]
parts: Identify this task, the first attempt at which involved a collaboration with Alexander Mozer in 1912, but was called off. In the composer’s lifetime, the most authentic attempt at this task was attempted by Modest Altschuler (“ALT-shoo-lur”) at Carnegie Hall in 1915.

Mozer attempted to build this instrument to perform Scriabin’s Prometheus and the New York Philharmonic actually managed to do so. This instrument may have been intended to evoke synesthesia for the audience.

If you order the notes on the color organ from Prometheus in accordance with this construct from music theory, they form a normal spectrum: for example, F is deep red, C is red, G is orange, D is yellow, and so on.

bonuses.leadin: At the opening of the novel she appears in, this character is described as knowing so little of “lords and baronets” that she entertained no notion of their general mischievousness. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this mother of ten children who, in one of her last appearances, calls the protagonist a “scatter-brained” creature after being informed of the novel’s events. Ultimately, she opines “Well, we must live and learn.”
Mrs. Morland is the mother of Catharine Morland in this posthumously-published novel by Jane Austen.

In Northanger Abbey, Mrs. Morland reads Pope, Gray, Thompson and Shakespeare to supply quotations to become one of these figures. The novel opens with the observation that “in her infancy” no one would have supposed Catherine to be born one of these people.

bonuses.leadin: This politician repeatedly asked permission from Puritan churches to hold Church of England services there, which convinced the locals that he was part of a Popish Plot. For 10 points each:
answers: Simon Bradstreet [prompt on Bradstreet] (Yes, the husband of Anne!)
parts: Name this Royalist who was overthrown in a coup by a violent mob after he attempted to enforce the Navigation Acts and harmonize local laws with those of England.

This politician, called the “Nestor of New England” by Cotton Mather, led the mob that came to Andros’s house and wrote a letter that convinced him to surrender. After that, this politician became governor of Massachusetts for a second time.
This tree in Connecticut got its name because a cavity within it was supposedly used to hide an important state document from Edmund Andros and the government of the Dominion of New England.

bonuses.leadin: In January 2021, Joe Biden issued Executive Order 13944, directing the FDA to compile one of these lists. For 10 points each:
answers: list of essential medicines [or essential drugs; accept EML or WHO Model List of Essential Medicines; prompt on less specific answers such as drug list or medicine list]
children [or kids; prompt on youth; reject “little adults”]
antibiotic resistance [accept antimicrobial for “antibiotic”; accept any answer referring to pathogens either resisting antibiotics or becoming immune to antibiotics]
parts: Name these lists. The WHO (“W-H-O”) maintains the most widely-used example of these lists and published the first of them in 1977, with 208 entries including lidocaine and hydrocortisone.

In 2007, the WHO introduced a separate list of essential medicines for these people, including alternate formulations of antimalarial drugs. Research hospitals focused on these people include St. Jude.

In preparing the 2017 edition of its Essential Medicines List, the WHO created the AWaRe classification system to help deal with this issue, which the WHO also addressed in the "Handle With Care" campaign.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about speleogenesis, or the formation of caves.
answers: the direction that water enters [accept answers indicating that the source of water is different; accept the specific answer that hypogenic caves form as water ascends from an underlying aquifer while epigenetic caves form as water descends from the surfaces
parts: Caves often form as the result of acidic water dissolving this rock, which is similar to dolomite.

Description acceptable. The formation of hypogenic and epigenetic caves differs in this key aspect. Because of their difference in this factor, hypogenic caves are regional systems while epigenetic caves are mostly local.

During pāhoehoe flows, the sides congeal and the surface crusts over, creating these structures, which leave behind long, linear caves once the lava empties out. The roofs of these structures are prone to collapse, leaving behind skylights.

bonuses.leadin: In the Ashkar-Gilson Manuscript, this passage is arranged in a "brick layout," where inscribed text was placed over uninscribed text. For 10 points each:
answers: Song of the Sea [or Shirat HaYam; or Az Yashir Moshe; or Song of Moses; or Mi Chamocha; prompt on Exodus 15:1-18]
parts: Name this passage in Exodus, which is believed to be among the most ancient portions of the Tanakh. This passage begins with the line, "I will sing to the Lord / for he is highly exalted" before describing the destruction of Pharaoh's soldiers and chariots.

The Song of the Sea is followed by a very short “song” of this woman, which actually just repeats the opening stanza of the Song of the Sea. This sister of Moses joined Aaron in criticizing Moses for marrying a Cushite woman.
Another very old song in the Tanakh is named for this judge, who mockingly describes Sisera's mother waiting for her son's return while celebrating Barak's victory over the Canaanites.

bonuses.leadin: The narrator’s paternal grandmother loses consciousness after she sees a large snake on the day she expected to see her son in a story set during this war titled “The Rainy Spell.” For 10 points each:
answers: Korean War [or Korean Civil War] (The clue is from Ha Jin’s War Trash.)
cranes [or durumi or tsuru; accept Thousand Cranes or Senbazuru]
guests [accept The Guest or Sonnim or “The Guest” or “L'Hôte”]
parts: Name this conflict. In a novel, a prisoner taken during this conflict takes up daily Bible study after meeting Father Woodworth, and is later forced to receive a tattoo.

In a Hwang Sun-won story set during the war, a soldier and a captive recall tying these animals up in a field. These animals title a Yasunari Kawabata novel in which Kikuji has an affair with Mrs. Ota.

One of these people titles Hwang Sok-Yong’s novel about the false attribution of the Sinchon massacre to the Americans, which is structured based on a shamanic ritual. These people title a story in which Daru meets the gendarme Balducci, who leads an Arab prisoner with a rope.

bonuses.leadin: In a letter to Archdeacon Fisher, this artist wrote that “the sky” is the “chief organ of sentiment” and “the standard of scale” in his paintings. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this artist whose paintings include studies of Cirrus Clouds and Cumulus Clouds. His depiction of Old Sarum includes thunderclouds amidst a “wild autumnal evening.”

Grief from the death of Constable’s beloved Maria in 1829 likely inspired the incredibly turbulent sky in his “six-footer” painting depicting this castle, which was the only ruin that Constable painted.

One year after finishing his painting of Hadleigh Castle, Constable made one of his several paintings of this cathedral. The painting showing it “From the Meadows” includes a rainbow cutting into dark clouds, which critics have interpreted as Constable processing his grief over the death of his wife.

bonuses.leadin: This work’s mention of the “King of Gold and Silver,” whose empire covered half of the world, is today usually interpreted as a reference to Alexander the Great. For 10 points each:
answers: The Epic of Sundiata [accept any answers mentioning Sundiata or Sunjata]
griots [or jali, or jeli, or kevel, or okawul, or gewel]
parts: Name this work which describes the creation of a constitution called the Kouroukan Fouga, under which “quiver-carrying” families were responsible for collective defense.

Sundiata proclaims the Kouroukan Fouga in front of an assembly of kings at this place, which some historians thus argue was the first capital of the Mali empire, before Niani. It is commonly identified with a town in Western Mali, where people still re-enact the epic’s events by rebuilding the sacred kamablo house every seven years.
At the gatherings in Kangaba, many of these West African bards come to tell the tale of Sundiata.

bonuses.leadin: This adjective describes a derivative whose Riemann–Liouville and Caputo definitions differ simply in the order in which an integral described by this adjective is applied. For 10 points each:
answers: Riesz [or Marcel Riesz; or Frigyes Riesz] (They are brothers!)
parts: Name this adjective that describes an integral obtained by modifying the Cauchy formula for repeated integration.
Both definitions of the fractional derivative use this function to remove the discrete factorial in the Cauchy formula. This function extends the factorial to the complex plane.

A Hungarian mathematician with this last name introduced fractional potential operators for analyzing the wave equation. Another mathematician with this last name has a representation theorem that shows that any bounded linear functional on a Hilbert space can be represented as an inner product.

bonuses.leadin: According to the biography Crooked Cucumber, after a student questioned the value of this man's writings, he was referred to as a "great Bodhisattva" by the author of Zen Mind, Beginner's Mind. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this philosopher and writer who helped popularize Taoism and Zen in the western world. This man positively compared modern psychedelics to the quest for the elixir of immortality in his essay "The New Alchemy."

In The Spirit of Zen, Watts criticized his early writings for only copying the work of this other Zen philosopher. This author of An Introduction to Zen Buddhism has been criticized in modern times for his approving statements about the Nazi party and for integrating Zen into Nihonjinron nationalist philosophy.

D. T. Suzuki did not reciprocate Watts' appreciation, accusing Watts of dismissing zazen on the basis of half of a misinterpreted one of these statements. A famous one of these statements says "If you meet the Buddha, kill him."
